items.title: What new legal challenges mean for the future of US offshore wind
items.summary: For offshore wind power in the US, the new year is bringing new legal battles. On December 22, the Trump administration announced it would pause the leases of five wind farms currently under construction off the US East Coast. Developers were ordered to stop work immediately. The cited reason? Natiโฆ
items.body: For offshore wind power in the US, the new year is bringing new legal battles. On December 22, the Trump administration announced it would pause the leases of five wind farms currently under construction off the US East Coast. Developers were ordered to stop work immediately. The cited reason? National security, specifically concerns that turbines can cause radar interference. But thatโs a known issue, and developers have worked with the government to deal with it for years. Companies have been quick to file lawsuits, and the court battles could begin as soon as this week. Hereโs what the latest kerfuffle might mean for the struggling offshore wind industry in the US. This pause affects $25 billion in investment in five wind farms: Vineyard Wind 1 off Massachusetts, Revolution Wind off Rhode Island, Sunrise Wind and Empire Wind off New York, and Coastal Virginia Offshore Wind off Virginia. Together, those projects had been expected to create 10,000 jobs and power more than 2.5 million homes and businesses. In a statement announcing the move, the Department of the Interior said that โrecently completed classified reportsโ revealed national security risks, and that the pause would gโฆ

items.title: Deploying a hybrid approach to Web3 in the AI era
items.summary: When the concept of โWeb 3.0โ first emerged about a decade ago the idea was clear: Create a more user-controlled internet that lets you do everything you can now, except without servers or intermediaries to manage the flow of information. Where Web2, which emerged in the early 2000s, relies on centโฆ
items.body: When the concept of โWeb 3.0โ first emerged about a decade ago the idea was clear: Create a more user-controlled internet that lets you do everything you can now, except without servers or intermediaries to manage the flow of information. Where Web2, which emerged in the early 2000s, relies on centralized systems to store data and supply compute, all ownedโand monetized byโa handful of global conglomerates, Web3 turns that structure on its head. Instead, data and compute are decentralized through technologies like blockchain and peer-to-peer networks. What was once a futuristic concept is quickly becoming a more concrete reality, even at a time when Web2 still dominates. Six out of ten Fortune 500 companies are exploring blockchain-based solutions, most taking a hybrid approach that combines traditional Web2 business models and infrastructure with the decentralized technologies and principles of Web3. Popular use cases include cloud services, supply chain management, and, most notably financial services. In fact, at one point, the daily volume of transactions processed on decentralized finance exchanges exceeded $10 billion . Gaining a Web3 edge Among the advantages of Web3 for thโฆ

items.title: LLMs contain a LOT of parameters. But whatโs a parameter?
items.summary: MIT Technology Review Explains: Let our writers untangle the complex, messy world of technology to help you understand whatโs coming next. You can read more from the series here. I am writing this because one of my editors woke up in the middle of the night and scribbled on a bedside notepad: โWhatโฆ
items.body: MIT Technology Review Explains: Let our writers untangle the complex, messy world of technology to help you understand whatโs coming next. You can read more from the series here . I am writing this because one of my editors woke up in the middle of the night and scribbled on a bedside notepad: โWhat is a parameter?โ Unlike a lot of thoughts that hit at 4 a.m., itโs a really good questionโone that goes right to the heart of how large language models work. And Iโm not just saying that because heโs my boss. (Hi, Boss!) A large language modelโs parameters are often said to be the dials and levers that control how it behaves. Think of a planet-size pinball machine that sends its balls pinging from one end to the other via billions of paddles and bumpers set just so. Tweak those settings and the balls will behave in a different way.   OpenAIโs GPT-3, released in 2020, had 175 billion parameters. Google DeepMindโs latest LLM, Gemini 3, may have at least a trillionโsome think itโs probably more like 7 trillionโbut the company isnโt saying. (With competition now fierce, AI firms no longer share information about how their models are built.) But the basics of what parameters are aโฆ

items.title: The man who made India digital isnโt done yet
items.summary: Nandan Nilekani canโt stop trying to push India into the future. He started nearly 30 years ago, masterminding an ongoing experiment in technological state capacity that started with Aadhaarโthe worldโs largest digital identity system. Aadhaar means โfoundationโ in Hindi, and on that bedrock Nilekaโฆ
items.body: Nandan Nilekani canโt stop trying to push India into the future. He started nearly 30 years ago, masterminding an ongoing experiment in technological state capacity that started with Aadhaarโthe worldโs largest digital identity system. Aadhaar means โfoundationโ in Hindi, and on that bedrock Nilekani and people working with him went on to build a sprawling collection of free, interoperating online tools that add up to nothing less than a digital infrastructure for society. They cover government services, digital payments, banking, credit, and health care, offering convenience and access that would be eye-popping in wealthy countries a tenth of Indiaโs size. In India those systems are called, collectively, โdigital public infrastructure,โ or DPI. At 70 years old, Nilekani should be retired. But he has a few more ideas. Indiaโs electrical grid is creaky and prone to failure; Nilekani wants to add a layer of digital communication to stabilize it. And then thereโs his idea to expand the financial functions in DPI to the rest of the world, creating a global digital backbone for commerce that he calls the โfinternet.โ โIt sounds like some crazy stuff,โ Nilekani says. โBut I think these โฆ

items.summary: Water shortages in Southern California made an indelible impression on Evelyn Wang โ00 when she was growing up in Los Angeles. โI was quite young, perhaps in first grade,โ she says. โBut I remember we werenโt allowed to turn our sprinklers on. And everyone in the neighborhood was given disinfectantโฆ
items.body: Water shortages in Southern California made an indelible impression on Evelyn Wang โ00 when she was growing up in Los Angeles. โI was quite young, perhaps in first grade,โ she says. โBut I remember we werenโt allowed to turn our sprinklers on. And everyone in the neighborhood was given disinfectant tablets for the toilet and encouraged to keep flushing to a minimum. I didnโt understand exactly what was happening. But I saw that everyone in the community was affected by the scarcity of this resource.โ Today, as extreme weather events increasingly affect communities around the world, Wang is leading MITโs effort to tackle the interlinked challenges of a changing climate and a burgeoning global demand for energy. Last April, after wrapping up a two-year stint directing the US Department of Energyโs Advanced Research Projects AgencyโEnergy (ARPA-E), she returned to the campus where sheโd been both an undergraduate and a faculty member to become the inaugural vice president for energy and climate.  โThe accelerating problem of climate change and its countless impacts represent the greatest scientific, technical, and policy challenge of this or any age,โ MIT President Sally Kornbluโฆ

items.title: Starstruck
items.summary: Few people, if any, contemplate starsโcelestial or cinematicโthe way Aomawa Shields does. An astronomer and astrobiologist, Shields explores the potential habitability of planets beyond our solar system. But she is also a classically trained actorโand thatโs helped shape her professional trajectoryโฆ
items.body: Few people, if any, contemplate starsโcelestial or cinematicโthe way Aomawa Shields does.  An astronomer and astrobiologist, Shields explores the potential habitability of planets beyond our solar system. But she is also a classically trained actorโand thatโs helped shape her professional trajectory in unexpected ways.  Today, Shields is an associate professor in the Department of Physics and Astronomy at the University of California, Irvine, where she oversees a research team that uses computer models to explore conditions on exoplanets, or planets that revolve around stars other than the sun. But while searching for life many light-years away is her day job, creative endeavors round out her purpose on Earth. In 2023 Shields published a memoir, Life on Other Planets: A Memoir of Finding My Place in the Universe . She has started an influential educational program that encourages young girls to explore space, given a hugely popular TED Talk about how weโll find life on other planets, and won a string of prestigious academic awards, honors, and grants. She also plays the violin, cooks, practices yoga, and is a mom. And as what she calls a โrest leaderโโa professional propโฆ

items.title: Dennis Whyteโs fusion quest
items.summary: Ever since nuclear fusion was discovered in the 1930s, scientists have wondered if we could somehow replicate and harness the phenomenon behind starlightโthe smashing together of hydrogen atoms to form helium and a stupendous amount of clean energy. Fusing hydrogen would yield 200 million times morโฆ
items.body: Ever since nuclear fusion was discovered in the 1930s, scientists have wondered if we could somehow replicate and harness the phenomenon behind starlightโthe smashing together of hydrogen atoms to form helium and a stupendous amount of clean energy. Fusing hydrogen would yield 200 million times more energy than simply burning it. Unlike nuclear fission, which powers the worldโs 440 atomic reactors, hydrogen fusion produces no harmful radiation, only neutrons that are captured and added back to the reaction. Instead of radioactive wastes with long, lethal half-lives, fusionโs by-product is helium, the most stable elementโand a yearโs worth from a fusion plant wouldnโt supply a party balloon business. Dennis Whyteโs part in the fusion quest began in graduate school, in a lab belonging to the electric utility Hydro-Quรฉbec, just outside Montreal. There he was shown a device built to replicate stellar fusion on an earthly scale. It was a doughnut-shaped hollow chamber, big enough for a lanky physicist like him to stand inside, based on a design conceived in 1950 by the future Nobel Peace Prize laureate Andrei Sakharov, who also developed hydrogen bombs for the Soviet Union. It was callโฆ

items.title: Hands-on engineering
items.summary: Jaden Chizuruoke May โ29 worked with teammates Rihanna Arouna โ29 and Marian Akinsoji โ29 to design the chemically powered model car whose framework he is building in this scene from the Huang-Hobbs BioMaker Space, where students have a chance to work safely and independently with biological systemโฆ
items.body: Jaden Chizuruoke May โ29 worked with teammates Rihanna Arouna โ29 and Marian Akinsoji โ29 to design the chemically powered model car whose framework he is building in this scene from the Huang-Hobbs BioMaker Space, where students have a chance to work safely and independently with biological systems. The assignment to build the carโand the layered electrochemical battery that powers itโcame in a class called โHands-On Engineering: Squishy Style Making with Biology and Chemistryโ taught by the labโs director, Justin Buck, PhD โ12. โIt is definitely one of my favorite classes,โ says May, who appreciates that after being trained, students are given the freedom to figure out how to tackle each task in a project. Located in the basement of Building 26, the BioMaker Space welcomes novices and expert mentors alike, offering workshops in such things as bacterial photography, biobots, lateral flow assay, CRISPR, and DNA origami. For May, the makerspace has been a hub for collaboration. โI could never have done anything in that lab without my peers and counselors helping me, and the emphasis placed on teamwork is what makes the class feel both welcoming and exciting,โ he says, adding that hโฆ

items.title: Investing in the promise of quantum
items.summary: As MIT navigates a difficult and constantly changing higher education landscape, I believe our best response is not easy but simple: Keep doing our very best work. The presidential initiatives weโve launched since fall 2024 are a vital part of our strategy to advance excellence within and across hiโฆ
items.body: As MIT navigates a difficult and constantly changing higher education landscape, I believe our best response is not easy but simple: Keep doing our very best work. The presidential initiatives weโve launched since fall 2024 are a vital part of our strategy to advance excellence within and across high-impact fields, from health care, climate, and education to AI and manufacturingโand now quantum. On December 8, we launched Quantum at MIT, or QMIT โthe name rhymes with qubit , the basic unit of quantum informationโto elevate MITโs long-standing strengths in quantum science and engineering across computing, communication, and sensing. More than 40 years ago, MIT helped kick off what is widely considered the second quantum revolution as host of the first Physics of Computation Conference at Endicott House, bringing together physics and computing researchers to explore the promise of quantum computing. Now weโre investing further in that promise. Like all MITโs strategic priorities, QMIT will help ensure that new technologies are used for the benefit of society. Faculty director Danna Freedman , the Frederick George Keyes Professor of Chemistry, is leading the initiative with a focus tโฆ
